title: Super-Wide JNCO Jeans—A Polarizing ’90s Trend—Are Back
sub_head: Millennials and Gen-Z’ers are snatching up gigantic JNCO jeans, drawn to their curious width and pre-Y2K cool factor.
body:
In the 1990s, JNCO jeans were big—in every sense of the term. With hulking legs (imagine fitting a 2-liter bottle of Coke horizontally across the hem), JNCOs were the street-sweeping denims that raver kids, graffiti artists, skateboarders and those pretending to be part of those subcultures wore. They represented a generational divide, tut-tutted by straight-leg Lee-wearing dads and even banned by some school districts who considered them unsightly. The controversy only bolstered JNCO, whose parent company Revatex reached $186.9 million in sales in 1998. But the success withered fast. In the early 2000s, JNCO’s wide jeans were supplanted by skinny jeans which clenched calves across America.
Now progressive young shoppers are reviving JNCO’s jumbo-sized jeans. Depop, a youth-leaning resale website, reported that between spring 2021 and today, it has seen a 30% increase in searches for JNCOs and a 35% increase for “wide leg” jeans more broadly. “As we emerged from the pandemic earlier in the year, we also saw more users going for a relaxed, baggy look,” said Lizzy de Bruin, a strategic inventory lead at Depop. At on-the-pulse vintage stores like Procell in New York City, vintage JNCOs are being resold for around $250. And the brand itself is in the midst of a slow-rolling relaunch.
